articles.headline: Radhika Jones, Vanity Fair’s Surprise Choice, Is Ready to Go
articles.snippet: A relative unknown prepares to follow Graydon Carter, who embraced the role of celebrity editor during his 25 years at the helm.
articles.abstract: A relative unknown prepares to follow Graydon Carter, who embraced the role of celebrity editor during his 25 years at the helm.
articles.lead_paragraph: Radhika Jones grew up around music. Her father, Robert L. Jones, a singer and guitarist, was a prominent figure on the Cambridge, Mass., folk scene of the late 1950s and early 1960s. When he decided he wanted to travel less, she sold T-shirts and worked the box office at the many events, including the Newport Jazz and Folk Festivals, he helped produce.

articles.headline: Roy Moore Is Accused of Sexual Misconduct by a Fifth Woman
articles.snippet: The new accusations came hours after Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, declared that he believes the accusers and urged Mr. Moore, a Senate candidate, to step aside.
articles.abstract: The new accusations came hours after Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, declared that he believes the accusers and urged Mr. Moore, a Senate candidate, to step aside.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An Alabama woman accused Roy S. Moore on Monday of sexually assaulting her when she was 16, the fifth and most brutal charge leveled against the Republican Senate candidate. Senate Republicans are now openly discussing not seating him or expelling him if he wins the Dec. 12 special election.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Navy SEALs Investigated in Green Beret’s Death Also Under Scrutiny in Theft
articles.snippet: The revelations that the SEAL commandos have been under suspicion of stealing money from a fund used to pay informants shed light on a potential motive in the mysterious Mali death.
articles.abstract: The revelations that the SEAL commandos have been under suspicion of stealing money from a fund used to pay informants shed light on a potential motive in the mysterious Mali death.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two Navy SEAL commandos under investigation in the strangling of an Army Green Beret soldier in June in Mali have also been under scrutiny in the theft of money from a fund used to pay confidential informants, according to three service members briefed on the matter.
articles.byline: By John Ismay, Eric Schmitt and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

articles.headline: Justice Dept. to Weigh Inquiry Into Clinton Foundation
articles.snippet: In a letter to the House Judiciary Committee, the Justice Department said it planned to pursue the possibility of appointing a special counsel to investigate the Uranium One deal.
articles.abstract: In a letter to the House Judiciary Committee, the Justice Department said it planned to pursue the possibility of appointing a special counsel to investigate the Uranium One deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department said Monday that prosecutors were looking into whether a special counsel should be appointed to investigate political rivals President Trump has singled out for scrutiny, including Hillary Clinton.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: An Open Door for Pesticide Lobbyists at the U.S.D.A.
articles.snippet: A former lobbyist for the pesticide industry now leads a deregulation team at the Agriculture Department. Visitor logs show that old ties remain strong.
articles.abstract: A former lobbyist for the pesticide industry now leads a deregulation team at the Agriculture Department. Visitor logs show that old ties remain strong.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a private meeting in September, congressional aides asked Rebeckah Adcock, a top official at the Department of Agriculture, to reveal the identities of the people serving on the deregulation team she leads at the agency.
articles.byline: By Danielle Ivory and Robert Faturechi

articles.headline: Navigating a Breathtaking Level of Global Economic Change
articles.snippet: Managing rapid change wrought by politics, technology and social media is testing the business world’s best and brightest.
articles.abstract: Managing rapid change wrought by politics, technology and social media is testing the business world’s best and brightest.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Confidence” is a curious word. It is derived, in part, from the Latin word “fides” which translates to “faith.” It is a feeling, an inner voice.

articles.headline: A Big Deal in Big Food, Irene Rosenfeld Retires From Mondelēz
articles.snippet: The C.E.O. of a huge food company is stepping down after more than a decade at the helm. She created value for shareholders, but consumer tastes are changing.
articles.abstract: The C.E.O. of a huge food company is stepping down after more than a decade at the helm. She created value for shareholders, but consumer tastes are changing.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORTHBROOK, Ill. — Irene Rosenfeld, the chief executive of the snack food maker Mondelez International, wandered through an ocean of processed foods one day recently, admiring her handiwork. The center aisles of Mariano’s, an upscale supermarket near the Mondelez headquarters, were stuffed with her company’s creations — Oreos, Wheat Thins and Ritz crackers.

articles.headline: Considering the Cost of Lower Taxes
articles.snippet: The American aversion to taxes is singular among wealthy nations and may have produced a government unequal to today’s economic and social challenges.
articles.abstract: The American aversion to taxes is singular among wealthy nations and may have produced a government unequal to today’s economic and social challenges.
articles.lead_paragraph: American tax policy must stand as one of the great mysteries of the global political economy.

articles.headline: ‘Lock Her Up’ Becomes More Than a Slogan
articles.snippet: Attorney General Jeff Sessions denies being influenced by the president’s public pressure as he considers authorizing a new investigation of Hillary Clinton.
articles.abstract: Attorney General Jeff Sessions denies being influenced by the president’s public pressure as he considers authorizing a new investigation of Hillary Clinton.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump did not need to send a memo or telephone his attorney general to make his desires known. He broadcast them for all the world to see on Twitter. The instruction was clear: The Justice Department should investigate his defeated opponent from last year’s campaign.
